title: Kirchhoff loop - pd between a and b in 3 circuits

content.question: Three identical batteries are connected to resistors in three different circuits, as shown in the figure. Let <math alttext="delta V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> be the potential difference between points <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> and <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math> in circuits <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, respectively. Which of the following correctly ranks the three potential difference values?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta V sub 1 equals delta V sub 2, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1 equals delta V sub 2, which is greater than delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1 is greater than delta V sub 2, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1 is greater than delta V sub 2, which is greater than delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="delta V sub 1 equals delta V sub 2, which is greater than delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
